document.docAuthor: Frolov, Andrey V. & Akhmetova, Lilia A.
document.docTitle: Cerhomalus absconditus Frolov & Akhmetova 2021, comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of the Afrotropical scarab beetle genus Cerhomalus Quedenfeldt, 1884 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Orphninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic revision of the Afrotropical scarab beetle genus Cerhomalus Quedenfeldt, 1884 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Orphninae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Laboratory of Insect Systematics, Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Universitetskaya nab., 1, St. - Petersburg, 199034 Russia.
Laboratory of Insect Systematics, Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Universitetskaya nab., 1, St. - Petersburg, 199034 Russia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Cerhomalus absconditus
can be easily separated from congeners by having the apices of the parameres rounded (in apical view), without semi-circular excavations ( Fig. 2G, J ) and without keels or fossae on ventral side ( Fig. 2K ), and the base of elytra with somewhat tile-shaped punctures ( Fig. 2 A–B).

n.sp. Petrovitz”; RMCA .

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2.
Cerhomalus absconditus ( Petrovitz, 1971 )
. A, C, E–G . Holotype, ♂ (RMCA). B, D . Paratype, ♀ (RMCA). H–K . Male specimen from Andrada, Angola. A–B . Habitus in dorsal view. C, D . Labels. E, H . Aedeagus in lateral view. F, I . Parameres in dorsal view. G, J . Parameres in apical view. K . Parameres in ventral view. Scale bars = 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO • 1 ♀ ; Équateur , Tshuapa , Etata ;
Aug.–Sep. 1969
; J. Hauwaert leg.; RMCA
.

This is the most widely distributed species of the genus. The majority of records are from the Congo basin, but the species occurs up to Cameroon in the north (no precise locality is recorded) and to the Ancient Plateau in Angola in the south ( Fig. 6 ).
